job_title: Dual Diagnosis Counselor in Portland, OR
pros: I had a positive experience working here and would recommend it. This company is doing really important work in Portland providing addictions services with withdrawal management, residential treatment, and out-patient. Their new center they moved to when they rebranded last year is really incredible, a lot of potential. I felt like I was engaged in a very meaningful job working here. I worked in the residential treatment side of the company mostly with the men's side. It was refreshing to be at a company in which I could collaborate with the leadership team in decision-making around patient care and my own workload/needs. Great team of people, a lot of kind heart-centered people. They are very generous with the amount of trainings they will reimburse for. Good deal on gym membership at 24-hour Fitness. I learned a lot working here, progressing significantly in my skills as a counselor. The pay was decent, for the type of position and experience I had, I'd say it's a little above average compared to some others I was considering when I chose to work here. This is a great place to work on your CADC, they are very supportive of that. When I was there, there weren't any clinical supervisors for my LCSW hours, but they reimbursed up to $200 for my outside supervisor which covered my sessions with that supervisor.
cons: Like any non-profit company I've been at, sometimes there was a bit of a disconnect from the higher level management team and people working directly with the patients, but it wasn't too bad compared to the company I was at before. It seemed like I was paying quite a bit for the health insurance I was getting, maybe a downside of being at a smaller company. This field in general has a lot of turnover unfortunately, so it would sometimes be more challenging when there were less clinicians to cover everything. There was the most turnover and lack of staff with the residential counselors, Fora could fix that if they paid the residential counselors more. More PTO would have been nice, it was definitely less than the last company I was at, but they do give a number of holidays off as well.

review_title: Some good, some bad...but mostly good
job_title: Information Systems Analyst in Portland, OR
pros:
The best part about De Paul is the people who work there. You can tell immediately how much everyone really cares about the clients, and they will bend over backwards to try and improve things. It can be very inspiring to see.

There are also a lot of opportunities for employee development. De Paul hires supervisors internally as often as they possibly can, so if you're interested in a management role, chances are you will find an opportunity at De Paul.
cons:
De Paul has two major issues - communication and transparency 

- Changes are communicated poorly or not at all. The company intranet is so old and unreliable that it's impossible to say what information on there is accurate and what isn't.

- There is little transparency in how decisions are made, or even by whom. The management at De Paul has a bad habit of making changes quickly, in secret, and with little communication to staff. This can result in a feeling of whiplash that is rarely (if ever) validated.

pros:
De Paul Treatment Centers serves an important mission in our community--helping people find freedom from addiction. Many of the staff are in recovery or are alums of the program. It is an inspiring organization to work for! The benefits are pretty good -reasonable health care rates, with vision and dental included. The PTO and paid vacation days are very generous compared to other companies, as is the employer matched 401k retirement plan. Flexible Spending Accounts let you save money for transportation, parking, or medical costs.

I love getting to work somewhere that makes such a vital difference in people's lives. My co-workers are wonderful and fun to collaborate with. Overall, I would highly recommend De Paul Treatment Centers as a great place to work!
cons: The salaries are not as high as some nonprofits, but seem to be about average.
